I simply do not understand why their latest shadow minister will not take notice of his own wife, who has told him that this is a very significant impediment to small business—she is a small business person—being able to employ new people. She complained about the level of red tape and regulation. We all know that it is there, and so do they. But they are not prepared to do anything about it.

answer.para: The Yellow Pages Small Business Index survey of October last found that Australia's small businesses still find it very difficult to hire new people because of Labor's unfair dismissal laws. Seventy-nine per cent of respondents thought they would be better off if exempted from unfair dismissal laws, 33 per cent would have been more likely in the past to recruit new employees, and 38 per cent would be more likely in the future to recruit new employees. COSBOA has estimated that some 50,000 jobs would be created if a small business exemption were introduced. So why is it that the Labor Party is opposed to these overwhelmingly sensible changes? We know from that same survey that only 16 per cent of Australia's small business proprietors voted for the ALP at the last election. According to that same survey, 61 per cent were very pleased at the election of a coalition government.

Why is it that Labor has got itself so fundamentally offside? Why is it not prepared to do anything about it? The answer lies in the usual place, and that is that Labor does not govern for small business, Labor does not govern for improving the economy and Labor does not govern to try to improve the level of employment in this country. Labor governments govern at the behest of the trade union movement.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know you hate it. What did we get from the Victorian State Secretary of the Electrical Trades Union recently? He said, `The reason unions affiliated with the ALP was to have the ability to influence political outcomes in the interests of members.' And he is opposed to any reduction from 60 per cent to 50 per cent. Madam President, that tells you what it is all about. Labor is not in the slightest bit interested in doing anything other than protecting its power base. We all know that this is not just a retirement village for hack trade union officials; this is a closed shop. Of the 20 most recently arrived senators on the other side, 17 were paid trade union officials. It is an absolute disgrace. They are not interested in good government. They are simply interested in making sure that they get a slice of the action and that they get the rewards. That is why they gave over $100 million to the trade union movement when they were in office.

answer.para: It ought to be clear that taxation reform is long overdue and that the unfair dismissal laws ought to go. But no, they are not only opposed to those; they also want to reintroduce secondary boycotts. In other words, when the unions say they want something, Labor says, `How high do we jump?' It is quite clear that if you are to get employment levels down in this country you have to focus on small business—not in the job destructing way that the Labor Party is proposing to do but in the sensible way that our taxation policy does, removing a whole raft of imposts. If we go down that path then we will have sensible rules for small business in this country.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister elaborate on a few more of the things that the Labor Party are doing to jeopardise this job growth?
—Order! That supplementary question is out of order.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Senator Herron. Minister, can you confirm that the government anticipates that private health insurance premiums will rise four per cent per year? Can the minister also confirm that such an increase would be twice the current inflation rate? Has the minister's attention been drawn to research from the Australian Consumers Association that indicates that much steeper increases have occurred over the past two years? What is the government's estimate for the anticipated increase in private health insurance take-up following the introduction of the proposed 30 per cent rebate if premiums increase by four per cent per year?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Evans for that question. It is another example of the failure of the Labor Party to understand in any way the various parameters that occur in relation to private health care or health care in general in this country. I point out that there are various models put forward and various prognostications given as to what increases might or might not occur. In the whole 13 years that the Labor Party were in power they never predicted it accurately at any stage.

answer.para: I mentioned the other day the then health minister, Carmen Lawrence, making predictions about how health insurance premiums would come down as a result of the measures that she put in place. In fact, they went up. It is inevitable that health insurance premiums will increase because there is an ageing population, there is new technology coming in, and there is a disproportionate membership of older people in the group carrying private health insurance. As is well known, two-thirds of health care costs are incurred by people over the age of 65. So it is inevitable that premiums will increase given that, as a result of the measures that the Labor Party put in place, we had that precipitous fall from 70 per cent to 35 per cent and the fact that we have a community rating principle whereby the premiums are equal for young people and old people. The four per cent figure has come forward; other figures have come forward.

talk.start.para: —You don't know.

—I don't know, Senator Faulkner, what the figure is, nor does anybody else, including you. Madam President, does Senator Faulkner have any idea? The Labor Party has no idea. It is impossible to predict what will occur, because there is a lag period. Dr Lawrence, when she was minister, predicted that it would be a couple of years—Senator Evans is probably not aware of that—before measures that were taken would have an effect in relation to health insurance premiums. So I am not in a position to prognosticate as to what it might be. I would be happy to know whether anybody could actually give an accurate figure.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I appreciate your conceding that the premiums will increase, whatever the level of support for private health insurance. You mentioned the question of modelling, which the last part of my question dealt with. Given that you are calling on the parliament, by way of legislation, to invest $1.4 billion of taxpayers' funds into a new scheme, will you table the modelling that the government has done to justify its assumptions and the expenditure of such a large amount of public funds?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I am happy to tell Senator Chris Evans what the modelling is. The government has estimated that the rebate will cost $1.38 billion in the first full year of operation. This figure includes an estimated $380 million for the current scheme. The rebate will not simply increase government expenditure on health. The department has estimated that the cost to the Commonwealth of health services, on average, for every uninsured person is around $1,041, whereas the average cost to the Commonwealth of insured persons is around $628 with the current incentive scheme and $814 with the new rebate. It should be fairly obvious to anybody on the other side that it is beneficial to have people in the private health insurance system because of the difference between $1,041 and $814. That is a $200 difference between those in the public hospital system and those in the private hospital system.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I refer to the many reports by Australian scientists about the threat to Kakadu world heritage values of the Jabiluka uranium mine. Minister, is it correct that public servants in Environment Australia have been asked to examine the background of Australian scientists who have criticised uranium mining at Jabiluka, looking for something which could discredit those scientists? Did you, your staff or the department's Secretary give those instructions? Do you endorse those instructions? Do you understand that directed or threatened science is no science at all? Will you now instruct your office and your department to stop this attempt to suppress science?

—This is the latest nonsense from the Australian Democrats. They started off by saying there were reports from many scientists. In actual fact, the overwhelming scientific evidence is that the Jabiluka mine can be conducted in an environmentally safe way and a culturally safe way. Why? Because science has monitored the Ranger mine for the last 18 years and has found that there has been no environmental damage whatsoever. That is the reality.

answer.para: Yes, we were critical of one submission last week which is now referred to by the Australian Democrats. This was from a group of scientists, some of whom, as I think we might have said last week, had never visited the site; scientists who made no submission on the environmental impact study on the site, and if they were genuinely interested in the issue one would have thought that would have been the time that they would have made such a submission; scientists who raised in their submission concern about the stability of the tailings dam, but there is to be no tailings dam. These were scientists who raised concerns about water being extracted from the Ja-Ja billabong, but they are not aware that no water is to be extracted from the billabong; scientists who complain that the water management system will only handle a one in 10 years rainfall event but the water retention pond at Jabiluka is actually designed to contain all the run-off—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. It is one of relevance. The minister has not addressed the question I asked, which was: did he, his staff or the department's Secretary give instructions along the lines that I mentioned?
—Senator Hill is dealing with the topic. He may deal with it in the manner in which he chooses.

—Madam President, I was talking about scientists who say that the water management system would only handle a one in 10 years rainfall event, when it is designed to handle a one in 10,000 years rainfall event. Just because a small group of scientists produce an argument, it does not mean they are right. The honourable senator should look at the balance of scientific advice. She will find that this proposal has been thoroughly evaluated over a period of almost three years. It has been found that it can be conducted in an environmentally safe way.

answer.para: Whilst I am on my feet, I want to add that I thought the submission that Senator Allison sent to the new chairman of the bureau in Kyoto was a national disgrace.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order in relation to relevance. I asked the minister a direct question and I have still not heard an answer to it.
—Senator Hill, I draw your attention to the question that has been asked of you.
—To the extent that she bases her letter upon false science, I say to her that it is a national disgrace to write to an international body to seek to undermine the Australian national interest.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Again my point of order is one of relevance. The minister has still not answered my question. I did not ask about my letter; I did ask about his instructions to staff in terms of the scientists.
—Senator Hill, I draw your attention to the question.
—She says to the commission, `Don't let the pressure of a few angry Australians—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. You made a ruling in relation to a point of order taken by Senator Allison. I believe Senator Hill is flouting your ruling. I ask you to draw his attention to the correct ruling you made in relation to the extraneous material he is bringing into this answer.
—I have drawn Senator Hill's attention to the question that was asked.

—This offensive communication was only bettered by the Australian Labor Party. I understand why Senator Bolkus is too embarrassed to be here today, because the Labor Party writing to Kyoto saying that this mine should be put on the endangered list is a demonstration of hypocrisy beyond anything I have ever heard. For 18 years they mined the Ranger mine. That did not threaten environmental values. Now there is a new underground mine, a much smaller footprint using much less intrusive new technology, and Labor writes to an international body to undermine Australia's interests, saying it should now be put on an endangered list. Forget the Australian tourist industry, forget the Australian mining industry—they will undermine any Australian interest if they think it will win them a short-term political point. Labor's behaviour in this matter is a national disgrace.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I think we must assume that the minister has in fact issued those instructions to try and discredit scientists. I refer to the six-month stay of execution recommended by UNESCO and ask: if the World Heritage Bureau finds that there are still problems with the effects of the Jabiluka mine on world heritage values after that six-month period, will your government stop the mine? Has the government advised ERA that they are proceeding with the mine entirely at their own risk?

—This mining proposal has been thoroughly evaluated over a period of almost three years. It has been found that it can be conducted in an environmentally and culturally safe way. It has all necessary Commonwealth consents to proceed. As far as the interests of the Australian government are concerned, it has every right to proceed.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that the private health insurance industry has just recorded its best financial year result in three years, with an extra $300 million from higher premiums and an extra $26 million paid out in benefits? Can he confirm that this translates to an increase in the average cost of health insurance of $60 and an increase in average benefits of only $11? What action will the government take to ensure that the benefits of the proposed rebate do not serve to further boost industry profits rather than increase member benefits?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Here we go again. It is easy to take a snapshot of time and take three years out of it. What Senator West should have asked was: what was the profitability over the previous 15 years? There would have been an interesting answer to that. The reality in relation to business, which the other side would not understand, is that there are periods of time when profits are made and there are periods of time when losses are made. These balance out. Otherwise the private health insurance industry would go broke, which is what the Labor Party wants in any case. They have deliberately attempted to produce a system where there is no private health insurance available. They are obstructing what we are trying to do in giving people freedom of choice by bolstering the private health system.

answer.para: The Private Health Insurance Administration Council has recently released its annual report on the operations of the registered health funds for 1997-98. As usual, the Labor Party has focused on the increase in premium income collected and the fact that benefits paid have not increased by the same amount. It is disappointing that the media did not report what has occurred in the previous years. What needs to be said and understood is that over the past 15 years premiums collected have increased by 213 per cent, but during the same period benefits paid have risen by 235 per cent. Over the last five years, the relativities have been the same. Premiums collected have increased by 15.6 per cent and benefits paid have increased by 18.9 per cent. Even Senator Faulkner would understand the difference between 15.6 per cent and 18.9 per cent. If this is not pessimistic enough in terms of the future of the industry, let us also look at the industry reserves in 1997-98. They fell by 2.5 per cent. Net operating profit for the industry actually showed there was a loss of $6.6 million.

It is obvious that on the one hand we have superficial media reporting on the state of the private health insurance industry and on the other we have fact after fact showing that the industry has been performing so poorly that it has little chance for a long-term future. No industry can sustain falling reserves, net operating losses and outgoings exceeding income.

talk.start.para: —Given that the government is proposing to pump $1.5 billion into the private health insurance industry, why doesn't it insist on a guarantee from the industry that premiums will not rise?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Again, there is a complete failure of understanding from the other side about guaranteeing premiums. I have already said that premiums will rise. You cannot guarantee that they will not rise, because we have an ageing population, people dropping out of private health insurance and the cost of the public sector patient is higher than the cost of the private sector patient. It is only for ideological reasons that the Labor Party is not supporting our proposal. We have to bolster the private health insurance industry. A parallel would be to close all the private schools of Australia and then dump the children on the public education system. That is what they are proposing to do; the similarities are there. I ask those opposite to use their brains instead of another part of their anatomy which they seem to be using in this regard.

—My question goes to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to a particularly alarming situation which has arisen in West Papua. I ask the minister whether he is aware that in the wake of the massacre in Biak in July, where more than 100 West Papuans were murdered, there is a proposal to raise the Morning Star, the West Papuan flag, tomorrow in West Papua? Is the government monitoring the situation whereby last Thursday two naval ships dropped members of the special mobile police force from the Indonesian Police, the army's second level special forces, navy special forces and 16 trucks at Manokwari? Are the Indonesian authorities confiscating the Morning Star flag as well as farm implements? Is a massacre possible tomorrow with the raising of this flag? The important question is: will the Australian government urgently contact Indonesian authorities to avert tomorrow any repeat of the Biak massacre?

—Senator Brown asked a question on 23 November about the Biak incident and I think I said on that occasion that we were concerned by the reports and that the foreign minister had raised the issue with both President Habibie and General Wiranto. If I did not say it on that occasion, I certainly advise Senator Brown of it now. We have been seeking, through our embassy, to ascertain the truth of the reports. There is no doubt that there has been civil protest and some violence. I did understand—I am afraid I cannot find it just at the moment—that there was an independent examination that very much questioned whether in fact the level of violence that Senator Brown refers to did occur. I will see whether I can get that information for him by the end of question time. In relation to the other matters, I have no information on them.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I find that answer totally unsatisfactory. I put to the minister and I warn the minister by way of question that, with the flag raising ceremony, there could be a repeat tomorrow of the earlier massacre in West Papua. Will the minister investigate the matter and urgently contact the Indonesian government to try to ward off that potential for a further massacre in our nearest neighbour, West Papua, specifically in Manokwari tomorrow when this flag raising ceremony occurs?
—I will refer the matters to Mr Downer.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Given that Senator Hill made the statement today that a healthy private system will take pressure off the public system, could you inform the Senate how many patients the minister estimates will no longer seek treatment in public hospitals as a result of the proposed 30 per cent private health insurance rebate? What will be the level of patient transfer from the public to the private system? What percentage of total government expenditure on health is the rebate expected to be?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —A number of questions were put by Senator Ray. I will seek information from the minister as to the numbers that are expected. I would think that it is impossible to quantify, but if there is a figure then I will get it from the minister and let Senator Ray know.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Are you saying, Minister, that you personally do not know the facts here, but they may exist, or that they do not exist at all? If they do not exist at all, on what basis can you make rational calculations and projections for the proposed scheme?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I did not say that there were no estimates; I said that I personally did not know them. If they are available then I would be happy to produce them for Senator Ray. As I mentioned in the previous answer, various projections have been put forward and percentages used. If they are available I will provide them.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation: Push Polling

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Minister, are you aware of the letter from the Australian Woolgrowers Association to members of the government accusing the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation of push polling during the period beginning 4 November 1998? Has AWRAP engaged in push polling in order to bolster its support and to try to defeat the motion of no confidence due to be moved by wool growers against the organisation in Goulburn today?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I have a recollection of reading about some allegations of push polling. I do not have any instructions on the matter, but I think it is fair to say that agri-politics are being played at their hardest at the present time in relation to the annual general meeting of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation. That has been confirmed from one of the highest levels of government. There are, in fact, three no confidence motions being considered by the meeting in Goulburn today. Many of the proponents of those no confidence motions would seem to be pursuing a broader agenda of asserting greater roles for growers, and even perhaps individuals, in the control of AWRAP and the Woolmark company.

answer.para: There may be some superficial logic in seeking greater accountability to levy taxpayers through this route, but most of what is being suggested is in direct contrast to the rules of corporate governance laid down by the Corporations Law. I think we have to be very careful to ensure that the demarcation line between legitimate agri-political activity and industry service delivery responsibilities is properly drawn. Certainly in a private company there can be no claim to a board position on the basis of representation and, generally speaking, it is not a desirable approach to take to simply argue that, because you have got a vested interest, that vested interest ought to be represented irrespective of the merits or other commercial considerations.

Madam President, I know it is very easy for those who might disagree with some of the lobbying tactics that are going on to characterise them in the way at least one newspaper article has done, but I simply say that you need to have a bit of a look below the surface to see what games are really being played here. Having said all that, I make it plain that the government does view these developments with concern, and we are aware of a level of significant frustration in the industry regarding the role of industry bodies in general, particularly in relation to the wool sector. We do not think, however, that the passing of motions of no confidence is likely to take the matter much further, particularly given that most of the proponents have not advocated alternative specific approaches to actually improve the situation; they have simply tried to somehow cast aspersions on the current process. But if there are matters that are of legitimate concern and that do indicate high levels of discontent within the industry then the government will certainly take those matters seriously.

talk.start.para: —Arising out of the question, Minister, are you aware of the Australian Woolgrowers Association's very detailed plan to replace AWRAP if the motion succeeds? What will the government replace AWRAP with, if the no-confidence motion succeeds, in order to restore confidence in wool industry representative bodies?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of any detailed proposal, but I can say this: if a no-confidence motion were supported by a majority of those in attendance at the AGM, it would mean that the existing board would be stood down until the government could appoint a new board, and we certainly would be concerned that that might send negative signals to customers both in Australia and overseas and to Woolmark licensees, who currently contribute more than $20 million a year. Whilst I think there may well be legitimate matters to be explored, I would hope that it does not get to the point where these frustrations are reflected in motions that might be somewhat premature, to say the least.

—My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that the government, and the Minister for Trade in particular, has been lobbying the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council to water down its proposal for mandatory labelling of genetically modified foods? Does the minister recognise that consumers are entitled to information on which they can base decisions about their choice of foods?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I have a brief supplied which I believe answers the majority of the question. Under current food legislation in Australia and New Zealand, new foods and food ingredients are not required to be assessed by regulatory authorities before they may be sold. This situation applies equally to foods produced using, for example, gene technology. In February 1997, the Australia New Zealand Food Authority produced a draft standard for foods produced using gene technology, which was released for public comment. The latter part of the question I will have to refer to the minister as it is not in the brief that has been provided.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister undertake to inform the Senate of the position the government will be taking on this issue at the December meeting of the Australia New Zealand Food Council?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —As I say, I will check with the minister to see whether that can be provided.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders: Small Businesses

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Herron. Will the minister outline what the government is doing to encourage small business development for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Eggleston for the question.
—Have you got a brief on this one?

—Not only do I have a brief; I have prepared it. The government is committed to economic development in the indigenous community and has actively promoted the growth of small businesses. This is the only way forward. Under the Labor Party we had the development of welfare dependency. There is only one alternative to welfare dependency, and that is to have genuine employment and self-sufficiency. In fact, that has been a cornerstone of my approach to the portfolio—that we must address the fundamentals. Indigenous people have an unemployment rate that is over four times higher than that of the general population. The complete failure of Labor's approach to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs during its 13 year in government is highlighted by the fact that, despite its expenditure of $16,000 million, 60 per cent of indigenous Australians remain dependent on welfare. It is vital for the economic and social wellbeing of indigenous Australians that they be given opportunities to overcome the great disadvantage that they face, and it is also critical in the reconciliation process.

answer.para: Last year I established the Indigenous Business Incentive Program to assist in the development of small business. In its first year of operation, the Indigenous Business Incentive Program provided establishment grants to 151 individuals and organisations totalling $17.4 million. I announced during the election campaign that the government will establish a new organisation under the ATSIC umbrella, called Indigenous Business Australia, by amalgamating the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation and the business programs administered by ATSIC.

Local and overseas experience clearly demonstrates that to be successful economic programs must operate on a purely commercial basis distinct from social considerations. The Commercial Development Corporation, with its present capital base of $61 million, has directly invested in 18 joint ventures, including property, mining, manufacturing and retail, agriculture, tourism and financial services. It provides employment opportunities for indigenous people as well as the opportunity of good returns to indigenous joint venture partners. The government is working with ATSIC to improve outcomes in the start-up of businesses and their long term success. I am pleased that ATSIC is presently looking at innovative ways of delivering business support services such as outsourcing programs to utilise the best possible business expertise.

There is only one way forward. The government supports ATSIC in its aim to achieve economic, social and cultural empowerment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The government has proved itself to be a good economic manager. This in turn benefits indigenous people in the same way as it assists the wider community. Interest rates for businesses and home loans are at record lows of around 30 years ago. We have low inflation, a budget surplus and solid growth which, as Senator Kemp points out, makes Australia the strongman of Asia. The Australian people were given a choice on 3 October: more of the same economic sunshine, or a return to Labor's mishmash of high taxation, high inflation and high unemployment which dragged Australia down for 13 years.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Prime Minister stand by the critical comments he made in 1996 about the growing levels of private executive remuneration packages? Has the minister's attention been drawn to recent reports on the salary packages of leading banking executives, for example the 44 per cent increase since 1997 in the salary package of National Australia Bank CEO Mr Don Argus, who now has a pay packet of $2.7 million? Is the minister aware that NAB's net profit fell by 9.4 per cent in the financial year 1997-98? What message does the minister believe this conveys to those Australians currently engaged in enterprise bargaining where pay increases are substantially linked to productivity improvements?

—My recall is that the Prime Minister was somewhat concerned by advice that was being given to the government on labour relations matters at a time when very high salaries were being reported in the press. I have no reason to believe the Prime Minister does not now hold the views that he held at the time. In relation to the engagement of the head of the National Australia Bank, I do not hold any shares but I would like to have invested in the National Bank a long time ago. In other words, I am saying that I suspect most shareholders in the National Bank would believe that it has been very well governed and very well managed.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of customer anger at the burgeoning levels of executive salaries at a time when bank fees are rising at many times the inflation rate and when branch service levels are constantly being slashed? When will the government insist on real customer service and productivity improvements being the basis for increasing executive salaries in the banking sector, as applies in workplace bargaining for the rest of the community, or does the government agree with the chief executive of the Commonwealth Bank that the community should be praising these highly paid bank executives?

—Most depositors, if they are annoyed, are annoyed with the margins on loans rather than the salaries of the executives of the bank. The answer is to provide a competitive banking system so that you get pres sures upon the bank which will give a best return to those who deposit and to those who invest. All of our reforms in the banking system have been designed to provide that competition, to provide a strong, competitive sector in response to market pressure that respects the interests of Australians in the bush and elsewhere who have special needs and who need to be serviced by a productive banking sector.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. How is the government assisting small business and rural and regional communities to maintain better services through the introduction of rural transaction centres? How does the government's record in the provision of services to the bush compare with that of the previous government?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Tierney will be pleased to know that the rural transaction centres will do a lot of things for business in the bush and a lot of things for people in the bush generally. What Senator Tierney might also be interested in, as someone who spends most of his time out in regional Australia, is what we will not be doing that the previous government did. For example, we will not be imposing on small business in the regions interest rates that exceed 20 per cent, as in Labor Party days. We will not be giving small business in the regions inflation rates into double digit figures. We will not be allowing wages to gallop ahead, as they did in Labor years when they ruined many small businesses which could not afford to pay them. Very importantly, we will not be increasing the cost of transport to the regions, as happened quite dramatically under Labor. And we will not be allowing the post offices to run down. Over 277 post offices closed down in regional Australia under Labor and Labor, did absolutely nothing about it.

answer.para: We will be providing some $70 million over five years to initiate rural transaction centres. That will come out of the sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra. It is absolutely vital that we get the support for the sale of the further 16 per cent of Telstra so that people in regional Australia can have access to these transaction centres. These transaction centres will add to the work that the government has done with their Credit Care initiative and will provide small businesses in those areas of regional Australia which do not have business banking with some elements of business banking. The rural transaction centres will help small business in regional Australia at a later stage by including videoconferencing, the Job Network, the Internet, private health insurance claims and Centrelink, and there will also be a range of federal, state and local government initiatives. These centres will be run by the local community or by small business in many of the very small centres. They will allow the pharmacy, the newsagent and the local corner store to add this range of services to their facilities.

Under Labor, banks closed down in the bush. Under Labor, many of the services that we in the regions used to accept as normal dissipated. We intend to encourage the banks and the credit unions to work with us, with local communities and, in many instances, with local government organisations to make sure that these services are available in rural and regional areas.

There will be benefits for small business. We are very keen to ensure that small business, particularly in rural and regional Australia, prospers because, as one of my colleagues mentioned earlier on, it is small business that provides all of the jobs in, and the bulk of exports from, rural and regional Australia. So we are very determined to make sure that they have the most appropriate form of assistance that is possible. The improved services will boost small business. Local business will be enabled to stay in the towns and will generate employment in rural industries. So it is a good news story for rural and regional business. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that, with the rural transaction centres, Minister, we are spending $70 million on putting real services into regional Australia. Minister, would you care to comment on Senator Forshaw's interjection about regional development organisations and the window-dressing approach to regional services undertaken by the last Labor government?
—Order! Senator, you should not in a supplementary question be asking the minister to comment on interjection across the chamber.
—Madam President, have you ruled it out of order?
—Yes.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—On Thursday, 26 November, during debate on the business of the Senate notice of motion for a reference to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee, the Acting Deputy President, Senator Reynolds, undertook to refer to me the matter of senators referring to copious notes.

speech.para: The prohibition on reading of speeches under standing order 187 and the practices relating to the use of notes have been considered by presidents and the Procedure Committee over many years.

It has been ruled that senators referring to intricate or technical matters may read part of their speeches and, particularly in that circumstance, may refer to copious notes. It has also been ruled that it is for the chair to determine whether the prohibition is breached and when these practices apply.
Senator Faulkner indicated that he was referring to matters of detail, and I consider that Senator Reynolds's ruling allowing him to proceed was correct.

talk.start.para: —I have some further information in answer to a question from Senator Harradine on intercountry adoptions with China, which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The information read as follows—

para.inline: INTERCOUNTRY ADOPTION AGREEMENT WITH CHINA

speech.para: Senator Hill : On 24 November 1998 Senator Harradine asked whether I, as Minister Representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, was aware that the Department of Human Services in Victoria had quoted an estimated cost of $A17000 for adopting a child under the proposed intercountry adoption agreement with China. This cost purportedly includes approximately $A8000 for immigration fees and court costs Senator Harradine asked whether these costs are prohibitive.

para.inline: RESPONSE:

speech.para: . The Victorian Department of Human Services advises the estimated cost of adopting a child from China under the agreement will be approximately $A16000. (This may vary according to exchange rate fluctuations.)
. The cost may vary according to the individual circumstances of a particular case, but may generally be broken down as follows:
- application fee for assessment of prospective adoptive parents by Australian state/territory child welfare authorities—approximately $A5500 (may vary from state to state)
- administrative costs in China—approximately $A6000
- certification of documents by the PRC embassy in Australia- currently being negotiated with the embassy
- cost of travel to PRC by the adoptive parents to collect the child and finalise the adoption approximately $A4000
- visa application charge—$A1060
- migration health check—approximately $A150 (dependent on the child's health status)
. as a comparison, an American couple resident in the USA and adopting a child from China would expect to pay costs ranging from approximately $A23000 to 32000

. compared with administrative costs in China of approximately $A6000 Australian couples wishing to adopt a child from other countries with which Australia has intercountry adoption agreements, may expect to incur administrative costs in the overseas country ranging from:
- Guatemala—approximately $A17700 to $A19300
- Romania—approximately $A7250 to $A15300
- Korea—approximately $A10500
- Thailand—voluntary contribution $A500
- Taiwan—approximately $A14000 to $A24000

talk.start.para: —I want to add my own personal comment. Despite the fact that this answer demonstrates that the anticipated fees will be lower than for a couple adopting from the United States and that the fees are comparable to adoptions from a number of other countries, they still do strike me as extraordinarily high.

—I have an answer to a question from Senator Bourne on reported killings in Alas in East Timor. The answer is that representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Jakarta and East Timor are investigating the reported killings. The ICRC is the competent international organisation which has standing to do so and has the necessary personnel on the ground.

speech.para: Ultimately, responsibility for clarification of the facts relating to incidents within the territory of the Republic of Indonesia lies with the Indonesian government.

talk.start.para: —During question time we sought information from our delegation in Kyoto regarding the allegations made by Senator Faulkner in his question today in which he alleged some sort of deal with Mexican delegates. The answer that I have got back is that no such deal has been discussed.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Fringe Benefits

talk.start.para: —Senator Crossin asked me a question on 25 November 1998 on fringe benefits and the proposed goods and services tax. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard responses to those questions.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The responses read as follows—
What will be the FBT impact under the GST regime for an employer who pays, or reimburses employees, for GST-free activities such as health, education or child care?

Will there be a different FBT impact under the GST regime for an employer who reimburses employees for a GST input-taxed activity, such as an employee who pays, or receives reimbursement for the payment of private rent?
The answer read as follows

Where goods or services are provided to employees as fringe benefits, the GST credit will be allowed but Fringe Benefits Tax will be adjusted so that there will be no advantage for the employer in providing benefits rather than providing salary.
Goods or services that are GST-free or input-taxed that are provided as fringe benefits will be subject to FBT in the same way as other fringe benefits.

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Answers to Questions

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the Government's proposed private health insurance rebate.
In doing so, I include the dorothy dixer asked of him by Senator Eggleston because I think, if anything, it was his most revealing answer on the health issue today.

In response to that question he referred to welfare dependency and his concern about it. What was revealed today in his answers was the creation of welfare dependency by private health insurance providers. That will be the impact of the government's measures as described by Senator Herron in response to the questions today.

The government's proposal to pour $1.4 billion of public funding into propping up private health insurance is a disgrace. It is welfare dependency at its worst. This private health insurance issue is a classic example of a government throwing money at a problem when it cannot come to grips with the problem. We have had a history in recent times of support measures for private health insurance, but numbers are continuing to fall and premiums are rising. The government has no idea how to control these increases in costs and the fall in private health insurance membership. So the answer is: throw more money at the problem. Throw $1.4 billion of taxpayer funds to the 30 per cent of the population who still take out private health insurance.

When asked to justify this the government can provide no modelling, no performance indicators—nothing to justify this, other than that it will be very popular with the 30 per cent of private health insurance members in this country.

I accept that those people struggling to pay quite expensive premiums will regard the measure as being of assistance. They will, in the short term. But—as they well know—what happened with the last rebate and what has happened in the history of private health insurance is that any support they receive will get eaten up in higher premiums.

There is nothing in this measure about capping of fees. There is nothing in the measure about dealing with the increasing administrative costs of private health insurance funds. Last year, their income went up by seven per cent and the payment of benefits went up by one per cent—they had a $300 million bonanza. This is the problem the government is seeking to fix by throwing another $1.4 billion of public money at it—it just does not make any sense.

My opposition to this measure is not ideological, it is economic. There is no basis for throwing $1.4 billion of public funds at what they perceive to be the problem. Even the government cannot provide any rational answer as to why they think that might solve the issue.

They claim, on their own figures, that it might increase private health insurance membership from 30.3 per cent of the population to 33 per cent—a very meagre increase in the percentage of people taking out private health insurance. So there is no pretence that this is going to solve the problem. It is a complete waste of money.

Today, in answer to my question, the minister provided figures which indicated that by providing this rebate the government will, in fact, narrow the difference between the cost to the government of those who are insured versus those who are not. He now says that the cost to the government of someone who is not insured is about $1,041 per annum, whereas with the rebate it will be only $814 for those who are insured. So the government is going to save $227 on costs per person if they are insured. But, on the government's own figures of the increased membership they expect to occur as a result of this measure, that will cost them $3,000 per head in government funds—to save $227. That is the economics of this measure—$3,000 per head of public funds wasted on a scheme to save the government $227 per annum per head, being the difference in cost between those who are insured and those who are not.

Those are the figures given by the minister today in response to my question. These are not my figures; they are his. As I say, this is not about the opposition's ideology; this is about the government's ideology. It is throwing public funds at a problem that they cannot define with a solution that they cannot explain. It is an absolute economic nonsense.

On top of that, the government seeks to maintain the effective one per cent less tax payable by high income earners who are insured. So they are going to provide a third subsidy by funding private health insurance for high income earners, who are also going to be given a one per cent tax concession at the other end. The effect of that measure is that the government is subsidising two-thirds of high income earners' private health insurance costs. The addition of the effective tax discount with the insurance rebate means that people on over $100,000 a year will have two-thirds of the cost of their private health insurance met by the government. This is social policy? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think there are some fundamental questions that need to be asked of the other side of this chamber. The first is: what is the Labor Party planning to do about private health insurance? Is it simply opposing the government's measures with no plan in mind? Is it simply hoping that private health insurance will die? I know the shadow minister for health, Jenny Macklin, has absolutely no plan whatsoever other than a zero private health insurance policy. I think that is very sad because, on top of what the shadow minister has done, there is a scaremongering process being undertaken today by the Labor Party, which is not at all healthy for the future of private health insurance.

speech.para: There is already talk about the funds increasing their premiums. The fact is that the Labor Party in government for over 13 years did not reject one request for a premium increase made by the funds. The difference is that when we came to government, we set up a formula and a procedure under which the funds had to apply for increases. At the moment, no fund has applied for a future premium increase. No premium adjustments will be considered before 1 May next year. If premium adjustments are necessary to maintain individual fund solvency—which is an equation that happens to be overlooked by the Labor Party—for the first time, they will be announced on a common day with no further increases for 12 months. As I said, the fact still remains that the Labor Party did not reject one request for a premium increase in their entire 13 years in government.

The fact of the matter remains also that funds will in future face a tougher regime for premium applications and the coalition is strengthening the power of the industry regulator and prudential supervisor, PHIAC.

The question still remains—what is the Labor Party policy? Do they simply want to abolish private health insurance? Do they want to make sure that it is tougher for the pensioners and low income earners to pay for their private health insurance? Because that is clearly what is going to be the result if the Labor Party and the minor parties oppose the legislation which will come before the Senate in the near future.

If the Senate rejects the rebate legislation, the funds will have to redraw their business plans and they will virtually have to increase their premiums. That would be as a direct consequence of the Labor Party policy. They do not seem to worry about that. They do not seem to worry that there are many low income earners who take out private health insurance.

Last week, we had the farce of the shadow minister suggesting some weird and wonderful way of calculating what would have to be reimbursed to the states. She made a comment that it was only going to cost the Commonwealth an extra $830 million if there was no rebate available. We currently have just over 30 per cent of people insured and it is a recognised fact, even by the Labor Party, that in five years time there would only be 20 per cent of people insured if there is no rebate. And yet the shadow minister said that it would only cost the Commonwealth government an extra $830 million. Heavens above!: she cannot even do her maths. She does not understand the Commonwealth Medicare agreement with the states. If what she is forecasting were to be the case, the cost to the Commonwealth would be close on $2.5 billion—not $830 million.

talk.start.para: —How much?

—It would be $2.5 billion, Senator Calvert—that is how much it would cost the Commonwealth. They do not understand that there are many low income people out there who desperately want this measure. For them to deny that measure, which the people voted for at the last election, would be, simply, to once again deny them the opportunity to make provision for themselves.

speech.para: It would be interesting to also ask how many of the higher earners in this place have private health insurance. It was interesting that Senator Lees declared on television yesterday that as a higher income earner she does not bother to take out private health insurance. It would be fascinating to know how many Labor Party senators and members have private health insurance where they bear the brunt of the responsibility themselves and do not share it among the other taxpayers and lower income earners of Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Knowles was talking about the Labor Party not understanding how tough it is on pensioners and low income earners when they are paying private health insurance. Well, we do understand how tough it is. For a low income family the cost of private health insurance ranges from $900 to over $3,000, Senator Knowles.
—Why do they take it out?

—Do you know why pensioners have health insurance that they cannot afford? They know the waiting lists are so long, they are scared and they need assurance, so they take out health insurance that they cannot afford. Your government wants to put in $1.4 billion to prop up private health insurance—throwing buckets of money at them, and for what? Senator Herron said today that it is inevitable that private health insurance will rise, so each year we pay more for private health insurance—
—Do you have private health insurance?
—Yes I do, Senator Knowles. I do have private health insurance.
—Senator Gibbs, would you please address the chair and ignore the interjections, which are disorderly.
—She is in a trade union as well.
—Absolutely—
—She got one thing right anyhow.
—You're trying to force people—
—Order! Senator Forshaw, Senator Knowles, Senator Calvert.

—People are paying into private health insurance when they cannot afford it, because they are terrified. Allocating $1.4 billion to prop up the private health insurance scheme is absolutely outrageous. Senator Herron said that it is inevitable that these fees will rise, so a family with an income of less than $70,000 will be paying, within less than two years, exactly what they are paying now. So it is not going to benefit those people. Putting $1.4 billion into the public health system in this country would be far wiser than propping up private health insurance companies. After all, even if you have private health insurance, if something diabolical happens to you, such as a heart attack or a stroke, you do not get taken to a private hospital. The ambulance person does not say, `Are you paying massive private health insurance fees? I'll take you to a private hospital.' No, you are taken to the public hospital because the public hospital has the facilities to cater for those things. The cost of the medicines and the equipment in the public hospitals is enormous. We need far more money in the public hospital system for the benefit of everybody in Australia.

question.para: Senator Herron today just could not answer most of the questions—absolutely not. He obviously does not know what he is talking about. I have a media release here from the Australian Consumers Association, which says:
A 30 per cent rebate won't get rid of the medical gap. For a total hip replacement, a private patient could face a gap payment of up to $890 for the surgeon's fee alone.

This is correct. If you go into a private hospital, the surgeon charges exactly what he likes. He does not charge you the Medicare schedule fee. You could be paying much more than the paltry sum your private health insurance makes up. In some operations you can pay $1,000 or $2,000 more because they charge exactly what they like and you have to cop it, and that is wrong.

talk.start.para: —That was under your system. That was brought in under Labor.

—No, if the surgeons have that problem, maybe you should look at that; maybe you should look at the details of the medical system in this country and start addressing them instead of trying to prop up private health insurance with $1.4 billion. That is absolutely outrageous and pathetic. The 30 per cent rebate will not address the rise in private health insurance either. (Time expired)

—I must say that Senator Gibbs's admission that she has private health insurance is really telling, because it means that Senator Gibbs as a Labor senator knows how inadequate the Medicare public hospital system is. She has just said that it is all about freedom of choice. In other words, if we take the case Senator Gibbs has just mentioned of somebody who needs a hip replacement, Senator Gibbs knows that that poor person who might need a hip replacement might have to wait 18 months or two years to get it done in a public hospital. Being a sensible person, Senator Gibbs—

speech.para: Senator Gibbs interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Because of the failures of your public hospital system under Medicare. Senator Gibbs knows that if somebody has private health insurance they will get their hip replacement done in a short time in a private hospital, they will get most of the fee back through the private health insurance system, and the person concerned will be up and about very quickly, rather than suffering through the 18-month or two-year waiting list for anything to be done in the public hospital system. That is the problem, you see. We used to have a very good hospital system in Australia where we had a nice balance of public and private hospitals. In 1983 the Labor Party, on an ideological high, introduced the Medicare system and set out to destroy the private hospital system and the private hospital industry.

speech.para: So what we have today is a situation where we have imported to Australia a system very much like the British National Health Service, with all its failures. Whereas before people were able to be treated quickly and easily, today in Australia we have a situation where we have overcrowded public hospital waiting rooms and enormous waiting lists in public hospitals because people have dropped out of the private health system, and the public hospital system has shown that it is not able to cope with the workload.

Even Graham Richardson, the former Labor health minister, said that if private health membership dropped below a critical level there would be a crisis in the Australian health system. We face that crisis now: private health insurance membership is down to some 30 per cent, the public hospital system cannot cope and waiting lists are growing day by day. So the government has decided to take a measure which will take the pressure off the public hospitals and see the underutilised private hospital system reactivated and working more smoothly again.

The benefits of this 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance will mean that some six million Australians will have an incentive to rejoin private health insurance funds. That will mean that public hospitals will have a lot of pressure taken off them, and the whole situation will improve considerably. It has been said that people on low incomes will be disadvantaged by this proposal.

talk.start.para: —Freedom of choice, Senator.

—Senator Gibbs, I believe that some two million people in this country with incomes of less than $30,000—which I am sure you on your income of $80,000 would not consider to be a high income at all—have private health insurance. So private health insurance is not just for the wealthy; it is for people who are concerned to ensure they get treated quickly in our hospital system. The Medicare system certainly does not provide any access to quick treatment.

speech.para: The question has been raised today about whether or not this 30 per cent incentive will draw many people back into private health insurance. The AMA believes that it will increase participation rates to some 45 per cent. They are currently on 30 per cent.

talk.start.para: —It is going to cost $2½ billion instead.
—It is $2½ billion well spent if it means that Australians get better and quicker health care.

speech.para: Senator Forshaw interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw, I cannot imagine you would like to be waiting around for a knee or hip replacement, or any other kind of elective surgery, in a public hospital when, if you were privately insured, you could get it done quickly in a private hospital. That is the benefit this measure will bring. (Time expired)

—Minister Herron is fond of referring to history when he stands up in this place. He never answers questions. It is interesting to look at a few historical facts. Firstly, which current political leader was a member of a government that abolished universal health coverage in this country? Of course, it was the present Prime Minister, John Howard, when he was a member of the Fraser government, which abolished Medibank.

speech.para: Medibank was established many years ago by a Labor government to provide universal coverage for all Australians so that they had an entitlement to decent health care in the public hospital system, but a coalition government abolished it. Which current political leader, when he was in opposition in the 1980s, swore that if he ever got back into power he would abolish Medicare? It was John Howard, of course, the current Prime Minister. He swore to abolish Medicare.

About two years prior to the 1996 election, John Howard, realising the error of his ways, said to the people, `I've changed my mind; I now support Medicare and I will do nothing to dismantle it.' But what happened after that election? Within 12 months his government brought in a budget that stripped $1.5 billion out of the public health system. They starved the states of vital health funds to run the public hospitals. We had the situation last year where every state premier and every state and territory health minister in this country was telling Dr Wooldridge and Mr Howard, `You are not putting enough money into the public health system.' They were telling this government, in the words of Jeff Kennett, that their private health insurance rebate scheme was a joke, that it was a mickey mouse scheme. That is what this government has done to health in this country.

When they were elected in 1996 they said they had the solution for private health insurance. They said they would bring in a scheme, take money out of the public hospitals—$1.5 billion—and pay an amount to private health fund members of about $450 a year and that that would increase the level of private health insurance. What happened? Membership went down by three per cent—and it is still going down.

These are the people who said they had the solution. What was Senator Herron's solution? It was to throw money at the problem. This is the same minister who says that the worst thing you could ever do to solve a problem in health in this country is to throw money at it. He lectures us time and time again. But that is what this government is proposing to do now: throw more money at the problem. They are proposing to throw more vitally necessary public health funds at the problem by taking it out of the public health system and giving it as a subsidy, basically, to private health funds.

When you ask what impact this is going to have, they say, `We do not really know—who can tell?' Senator Herron said that today. Senator Herron could not answer any questions. In response to the interjections, Senator Herron was only able to say one thing about what will happen after they give this $1.4 billion subsidy to private health insurance: premiums will still rise. They are going to rise by the order of four per cent. This government accuses the Labor Party of having an ideological objection to private health insurance. That is not the case.

talk.start.para: —You want to destroy the private health system; you want to destroy choice.

—We do not want to destroy choice, but we do have an ideological commitment to providing universal health cover for all Australians through the public health system. That is the priority of government. While we believe that there is clearly a place for a private health system in this country—and I acknowledge that I am, and always have been, a member of a private health fund—our obligation in parliament and in government is to put the funds into the public health system for all Australians. We should not take those funds out of the public health system and give them as a subsidy to private health insurance.

speech.para: If we do that, we will end up with a dual system like the one in the United States. People in the United States have access to a very basic level of care in the public hospital system at a much lower standard than in this country, and if you want to get decent health care in the United States you have to pay thousands upon thousands of dollars. That is the big difference between us and the coalition on this issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —If ever we doubted that this debate was ideological, we only had to listen to the speakers on the other side. Senator Evans opened his speech by saying that this is not an ideological debate and that he has economic grounds for his point of view. We never heard what his point of view was. I notice that Senator Ray is in the chamber. For the first time in the three years that we have been in government, Senator Ray has actually asked a policy question and tackled this issue.
—Do you want to bet that I have asked other ones?
—No, very rarely in this chamber have you asked policy questions.
—Order! Senator, please address the chair and ignore the interjections. All interjections on my left are unruly.

—If this were not an ideological matter for the Labor Party, they would have come up with an alternative public policy, and we saw none of that. That is known by all Australians. A number one issue for all Australian family households is the pressures and strains they are feeling in regard to health policy, and many are obviously at breaking point. Therefore, we went to the election with the policy of a 30 per cent rebate on private health cover. That policy was supported.

speech.para: I think the Labor Party must have a death wish not to support this tax rebate. What party other than the Labor Party in this parliament does not support tax rebates? They have an ideological bent against the private health insurance system. Senator Gibbs—who, by the way, is a self-confessed holder of private health insurance—talked about choice, yet she would deny that choice of access to private health to many other Australians.

As was said, over two million Australians who are in the private health system earn less than $30,000. They are under the greatest pressure to keep hold of their health insurance. They are the first to drop out of the system and be forced into the public health system, thus putting more pressures and strains on that system. The fall in participation in the private health system began in the Labor Party's term in 1983 when the private health system was at a healthy 60 per cent. By the time we got into office, it was around 34 per cent. We have halted that decline, but more must be done.

The first thing the Howard government implemented was the private health insurance scheme, which was the first genuine attempt in decades by any federal government to encourage people to go into the private health insurance system, giving them a greater freedom of choice between the private and public health systems. We followed that up with the extra one per cent Medicare levy for incomes over $50,000. I would say that that was about the only reason why the Senator Gibbs of this world took up private health cover.

We have put in place two initiatives to halt the collapse of the private health system. We now wish to bring in another initiative. It is calculated that for every one per cent of people who drop out of the private health system, some $83 million extra goes onto the states and territories to meet their health budgets. If the decline in private health insurance membership continues, it is calculated that by the turn of the century the federal government will have to find an extra $500 million for the states and territories each and every year just to keep the status quo.

Since we have been in government, we have increased spending on the public health system by over 18 per cent. We have not ripped the money out of the public health system; we have put more money into it, but we cannot continue putting money into it. It is far more economic and efficient to attend to the private health system.

debate.para: Motion (by Senator Calvert, at the request of Senator Hill) agreed to:
That the Senate—
(a) notes:
(i) the passing, on 19 September 1998, of John Henry Calaby, who rose from humble origins to become one of Australia's foremost naturalists, and
(ii) that among John Calaby's many achievements in a very productive life were:
(a) his close association with the successful introduction of myxomatosis for rabbit control in the early 1950s,
(b) his pioneering faunal surveys in northern Australia, including those in the Kakadu region which were instrumental in the eventual establishment of Kakadu National Park,

(c) his groundbreaking work on kangaroo physiology and reproduction, through close involvement in publications, in the making of the film, The Birth of the Kangaroo , and his contribution in helping Australians gain an appreciation for this supremely adapted animal,
(d) the establishment of the Australian National Wildlife Collection, a superb scientific collection of Australia's mammals, birds and reptiles, and

(e) his many contributions to the Australian National Dictionary of Biography , the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and the Council of the Museums Association of Australia; and
(b) expresses its condolences to John Calaby's wife Jo, their four sons and their families.

(i) the United Nations world heritage investigation team has recommended unambiguously that the Jabiluka uranium mine be stopped and that Kakadu meets all the criteria for the world heritage endangered listing,

(ii) the Australian Government has repeatedly and consistently got it wrong on Jabiluka, deceiving Australians about the impact of the mine and deceiving international forums about the impact of the mine on world heritage values,
(iii) the Australian Government has deliberately put itself in a position of having given all the permits to the mine and now saying it cannot stop it because of the potential compensation issue,
(iv) that there is no doubt the mine will impact severely on the indigenous Mirrar people of the area and destroy natural and cultural values,
(v) an endangered listing will negatively affect tourism,
(vi) the Government has not represented the majority of Australians, who want the mine stopped,
(vii) the Government's credibility on the environment is in tatters, as there can be no higher evidence that it is unfit to manage world heritage areas,

(viii) it is clear the processes for assessment under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 are completely inadequate for assessing world heritage and taking into account natural and cultural values,
(ix) a number of other mines are poised to go ahead inside world heritage boundaries, and
(x) sadly the Government's response is to attack the quality of the report and try to level inaccurate claims of bias;
(b) condemns the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill) for his determined inability to protect the values of the Mirrar people and the Kakadu world heritage area; and
(c) calls on the Minister to proclaim Kakadu a world heritage area under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and use that as the lever to stop the Jabiluka mine forever.

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to standing orders 38 and 166, I present the following documents listed on today's order of business at item 11 which were presented to a Temporary Chairman of Committees, Senator Sherry, on 26 November 1998:

interjection.para: . Committee report presented to the President since the last sitting of the Senate:

Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee—Report on the provisions of the Film Licensed Investment Company Bill 1998 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Film Licensed Investment Company) Bill 1998.
. Government responses presented to the President since the last sitting of the Senate:
Community Affairs References Committee—Report on housing assistance.
Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee—Report on marine and coastal pollution.
Finance and Public Administration References Committee—Second report on contracting out of government services.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with the terms of the standing orders, the publication of the documents was authorised. In accordance with the usual practice and with the concurrence of the Senate, I ask that the government responses be incorporated in Hansard .

interjection.para: The documents read as follows—
Government response to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee Report on Housing Assistance
Recommendation 1 :

The committee recommends that the Commonwealth government continue to support the expansion of research and data collection in all areas of housing, particularly those relating to the private rental market.

In particular, the committee recommends that additional funds be allocated to develop consistency, uniformity, standards (including a definition of `housing need') and benchmarks for analysis and evaluation purposes in all areas of research concerning public housing.
Response :
The Government notes the committee's recommendation. The Commonwealth provides a significant level of funding for housing research, including:
. 100,000 per annum under the Australian Housing Research Fund;
. 320,000 per annum to the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute; and
. 3.3m in 1997-98 and $1.7m in 1998-99 under the National Housing Priorities Appropriation.

The Commonwealth has worked to improve the availability of housing related data. There now exists a range of important measures of the effectiveness of housing assistance. For example, the CSHA has in place a range of performance indicators covering program outcomes and efficiency measures and this information is published in the Report on Government Service Provision.

Moreover, the previous and forthcoming ABS Housing Surveys will continue to yield important data on the public and private rental tenures, including levels of crowding, dwelling condition, and other satisfaction measures. The data available to DSS on the income support population is comprehensive and includes housing affordability outcomes of people on income support.

In relation to housing for indigenous peoples, the Commonwealth (ATSIC) provides funds to the Centre for Appropriate Technology for research into housing and housing related infrastructure for rural and remote communities.

In conjunction with States and Territories, the Commonwealth is in the process of updating the national data on indigenous housing and infrastructure needs previously collected under the ATSIC Housing and Community Infrastructure Needs Survey (1992). An analysis of the 1996 ABS Census data is also being undertaken to identify the housing needs of indigenous peoples throughout Australia.
Recommendation 2 :

The committee recommends that the Commonwealth and the States negotiate to reach agreement on affordability and adequacy benchmarks to be used in setting the common goals to be reached under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement.
Response :

The Government notes the committee's recommendation. At the meeting of Housing Ministers held in June 1997, State and Territory Housing Ministers agreed to examine their pricing policies. Most States and Territories are treating as a priority the redevelopment and upgrade of housing stock which is no longer appropriate or of an acceptable community standard. The committee's recommendation will be drawn to the attention of State and Territory Governments and Housing Authorities.
Recommendation 3 :
The committee recommends that the provision of public and community housing remain a joint Commonwealth State responsibility.
Response :

The Government notes the committee's recommendation. The future of Commonwealth and State roles and responsibilities in public and community housing assistance will be the subject of negotiation on arrangements to follow the expiry of the current CSHA in 1999.
Recommendation 4 :
The committee recommends that maximum rent levels and the rebated rent scales for public housing be included in future Commonwealth State Housing Agreements.
Response :
The Government notes the committee's recommendation. The recommendation will be drawn to the attention of State and Territory Governments and Housing Authorities.
Recommendation 5 :

The committee recommends that on its expiration on 30 June 1999, the 1996 Commonwealth State Housing Agreement be replaced by a new Agreement which retains the specification of performance and the strategic planning processes which are in the existing Agreement measures and addresses the issue of State accountability.
Response :

The Government notes the committee's recommendation. The issue of performance information and strategic planning processes will be the subject of negotiation between the Commonwealth and the States on arrangements to follow the expiry of the CSHA in 1999.
Recommendation 6 :
